The use of drones by police for surveillance purposes is subject to strict regulations under the Fourth Amendment of the US Constitution that protects citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures. 

In general, law enforcement agencies must have probable cause or a warrant before using drones for surveillance, and any surveillance must be consistent with the Fourth Amendment's privacy protections. This means that the police cannot use drones to spy on individuals without a valid reason or warrant.

However, there may be specific circumstances where the use of a drone for surveillance is lawful, such as during an authorized investigation or emergency situation. The legality of such uses would depend on the specific circumstances and the applicable laws and regulations governing drone use by law enforcement agencies.

If you believe that the police have violated your privacy rights by using drones to spy on you without a lawful basis, you may wish to speak with an attorney who can advise you on your legal options.
